content.content:
1‚Üí--- 2‚Üíname: auto-persist 3‚Üídescription: | 4‚Üí Activate this skill when building ANY dashboard that needs to store data. 5‚Üí This is the DEFAULT mode for all dashboard builds. 6‚Üí 7‚Üí Triggers: 8‚Üí - Building a new dashboard 9‚Üí - User wants to track, store, or manage data 10‚Üí - Dashboard has forms, lists, or editable content 11‚Üíallowed-tools: 12‚Üí - Read 13‚Üí - Write 14‚Üí - Edit 15‚Üí - Bash 16‚Üí - Glob 17‚Üí - Grep 18‚Üí - mcp__dashboard_tools__create_apps 19‚Üí - mcp__dashboard_tools__generate_typescript 20‚Üí - mcp__dashboard_tools__deploy_to_github 21‚Üí--- 22‚Üí 23‚Üí# Auto-Persist Skill: UI-First with Automatic Data Persistence 24‚Üí 25‚ÜíYou are building a dashboard. Follow this **3-phase workflow**: 26‚Üí 27‚Üí1. **BUILD UI** with mock data (understand what's needed) 28‚Üí2. **CREATE APPS** based on what the UI uses (automatic) 29‚Üí3. **WIRE UP** the UI to use real API (replace mock data) 30‚Üí 31‚ÜíAll three phases happen in ONE build. User does NOT need to ask for data persistence. 32‚Üí 33‚Üí--- 34‚Üí 35‚Üí## Phase 1: Build UI with Mock Data 36‚Üí 37‚Üí### Step 1.1: Design First (Use frontend-design Skill) 38‚Üí 39‚Üí**‚ö†Ô∏è ALWAYS start with design planning!** 40‚Üí 41‚ÜíActivate the `frontend-design` skill to create `design_brief.md`: 42‚Üí 43‚Üí```bash 44‚Üí# The frontend-design skill will: 45‚Üí# 1. Analyze the user request 46‚Üí# 2. Plan the UI structure 47‚Üí# 3. Define components and layout 48‚Üí# 4. Create design_brief.md 49‚Üí``` 50‚Üí 51‚ÜíSee `.claude/skills/frontend-design/SKILL.md` for details. 52‚Üí 53‚Üí### Step 1.2: Understand the Request 54‚Üí 55‚ÜíAfter creating `design_brief.md`, think about: 56‚Üí- What will users SEE? (lists, cards, charts, calendars) 57‚Üí- What will users DO? (add, edit, delete, filter) 58‚Üí- What data flows through the UI? 59‚Üí 60‚Üí### Step 1.3: Create Dashboard.tsx with Mock Data 61‚Üí 62‚ÜíBuild the full UI using placeholder data: 63‚Üí 64‚Üí```typescript 65‚Üí// Start with mock data to understand the shape 66‚Üíconst mockEmployees = [ 67‚Üí { id: '1', name: 'Anna Schmidt', role: 'manager', email: 'anna@example.com' }, 68‚Üí { id: '2', name: 'Ben Mueller', role: 'employee', email: 'ben@example.com' }, 69‚Üí]; 70‚Üí 71‚Üíconst mockShifts = [ 72‚Üí { id: '1', date: '2025-01-30', employeeId: '1', type: 'morning' }, 73‚Üí { id: '2', date: '2025-01-30', employeeId: '2', type: 'evening' }, 74‚Üí]; 75‚Üí 76‚Üífunction Dashboard() { 77‚Üí const [employees] = useState(mockEmployees); 78‚Üí const [shifts] = useState(mockShifts); 79‚Üí 80‚Üí // Build complete UI with all features 81‚Üí return ( 82‚Üí
83‚Üí 84‚Üí 85‚Üí 86‚Üí
87‚Üí ); 88‚Üí} 89‚Üí``` 90‚Üí 91‚Üí### Step 1.4: Prepare App Definitions 92‚Üí 93‚ÜíAfter building UI, prepare the app definitions based on what data you actually used. 94‚Üí 95‚Üí**Example for a shift planner:** 96‚Üí 97‚Üí```json 98‚Üí{ 99‚Üí "apps": [ 100‚Üí { 101‚Üí "name": "Employees", 102‚Üí "identifier": "employees", 103‚Üí "controls": { 104‚Üí "name": { 105‚Üí "fulltype": "string/text", 106‚Üí "label": "Name", 107‚Üí "required": true, 108‚Üí "in_list": true, 109‚Üí "in_text": true 110‚Üí }, 111‚Üí "role": { 112‚Üí "fulltype": "lookup/select", 113‚Üí "label": "Role", 114‚Üí "lookups": [ 115‚Üí {"key": "manager", "value": "Manager"}, 116‚Üí {"key": "employee", "value": "Employee"} 117‚Üí ], 118‚Üí "in_list": true 119‚Üí }, 120‚Üí "email": { 121‚Üí "fulltype": "string/email", 122‚Üí "label": "Email", 123‚Üí "required": true 124‚Üí } 125‚Üí } 126‚Üí }, 127‚Üí { 128‚Üí "name": "Shifts", 129‚Üí "identifier": "shifts", 130‚Üí "controls": { 131‚Üí "date": { 132‚Üí "fulltype": "date/date", 133‚Üí "label": "Date", 134‚Üí "required": true, 135‚Üí "in_list": true 136‚Üí }, 137‚Üí "employee": { 138‚Üí "fulltype": "applookup/select", 139‚Üí "label": "Employee", 140‚Üí "lookup_app_ref": "employees" 141‚Üí }, 142‚Üí "shift_type": { 143‚Üí "fulltype": "lookup/select", 144‚Üí "label": "Shift Type", 145‚Üí "lookups": [ 146‚Üí {"key": "morning", "value": "Morning (6-14)"}, 147‚Üí {"key": "evening", "value": "Evening (14-22)"}, 148‚Üí {"key": "night", "value": "Night (22-6)"} 149‚Üí ], 150‚Üí "in_list": true 151‚Üí } 152‚Üí } 153‚Üí } 154‚Üí ] 155‚Üí} 156‚Üí``` 157‚Üí 158‚Üí**Important:** The JSON must match EXACTLY what your UI uses! 159‚Üí 160‚Üí--- 161‚Üí 162‚Üí## Phase 2: Create LivingApps (Automatic) 163‚Üí 164‚Üí### Step 2.1: Call create_apps Tool 165‚Üí 166‚ÜíUse the MCP tool to create real LivingApps apps: 167‚Üí 168‚Üí``` 169‚Üímcp__dashboard_tools__create_apps({ 170‚Üí "apps": [ 171‚Üí // Your app definitions here 172‚Üí ] 173‚Üí}) 174‚Üí``` 175‚Üí 176‚ÜíThis: 177‚Üí- Creates real LivingApps apps via REST API 178‚Üí- Handles dependencies (employees before shifts because shifts reference employees) 179‚Üí- Returns metadata with real app IDs and controls 180‚Üí 181‚Üí### Step 2.2: Call generate_typescript Tool 182‚Üí 183‚ÜíUse the returned metadata to generate type-safe code: 184‚Üí 185‚Üí``` 186‚Üímcp__dashboard_tools__generate_typescript({ 187‚Üí "metadata": { 188‚Üí // The metadata object from create_apps response 189‚Üí } 190‚Üí}) 191‚Üí``` 192‚Üí 193‚ÜíThis creates: 194‚Üí- `src/types/app.ts` - TypeScript interfaces matching your apps 195‚Üí- `src/services/livingAppsService.ts` - CRUD service with all methods 196‚Üí 197‚Üí--- 198‚Üí 199‚Üí## Phase 3: Wire Up Real API 200‚Üí 201‚Üí### Step 3.1: Read Generated Types 202‚Üí 203‚Üí```bash 204‚Üícat src/types/app.ts 205‚Üícat src/services/livingAppsService.ts 206‚Üí``` 207‚Üí 208‚ÜíUnderstand the available methods: 209‚Üí- `LivingAppsService.getEmployees()` 210‚Üí- `LivingAppsService.createEmployee(fields)` 211‚Üí- `LivingAppsService.updateEmployee(id, fields)` 212‚Üí- `LivingAppsService.deleteEmployee(id)` 213‚Üí- etc. 214‚Üí 215‚Üí### Step 3.2: Replace Mock Data with Real API 216‚Üí 217‚Üí**Before (mock):** 218‚Üí```typescript 219‚Üíconst mockEmployees = [...]; 220‚Üíconst [employees] = useState(mockEmployees); 221‚Üí``` 222‚Üí 223‚Üí**After (real):** 224‚Üí```typescript 225‚Üíimport { LivingAppsService } from '@/services/livingAppsService'; 226‚Üíimport type { Employee, Shift } from '@/types/app'; 227‚Üí 228‚Üíconst [employees, setEmployees] = useState([]); 229‚Üíconst [loading, setLoading] = useState(true); 230‚Üí 231‚ÜíuseEffect(() => { 232‚Üí LivingAppsService.getEmployees() 233‚Üí .then(setEmployees) 234‚Üí .finally(() => setLoading(false)); 235‚Üí}, []); 236‚Üí``` 237‚Üí 238‚Üí### Step 3.3: Add CRUD Operations 239‚Üí 240‚Üí```typescript 241‚Üíasync function handleAddEmployee(data: CreateEmployee) { 242‚Üí const created = await LivingAppsService.createEmployee(data); 243‚Üí setEmployees(prev => [...prev, created]); 244‚Üí} 245‚Üí 246‚Üíasync function handleUpdateEmployee(id: string, data: Partial) { 247‚Üí await LivingAppsService.updateEmployee(id, data); 248‚Üí // Refresh data 249‚Üí const updated = await LivingAppsService.getEmployees(); 250‚Üí setEmployees(updated); 251‚Üí} 252‚Üí 253‚Üíasync function handleDeleteEmployee(id: string) { 254‚Üí await LivingAppsService.deleteEmployee(id); 255‚Üí setEmployees(prev => prev.filter(e => e.record_id !== id)); 256‚Üí} 257‚Üí``` 258‚Üí 259‚Üí### Step 3.4: Handle Loading and Empty States 260‚Üí 261‚Üí```typescript 262‚Üíif (loading) { 263‚Üí return
264‚Üí 265‚Üí
; 266‚Üí} 267‚Üí 268‚Üíif (employees.length === 0) { 269‚Üí return setShowAddDialog(true)} 273‚Üí />; 274‚Üí} 275‚Üí``` 276‚Üí 277‚Üí--- 278‚Üí 279‚Üí## Control Types Quick Reference 280‚Üí 281‚Üí| UI Element | fulltype | Example | 282‚Üí|------------|----------|---------| 283‚Üí| Text input | `string/text` | Name, Title | 284‚Üí| Long text | `string/textarea` | Description, Notes | 285‚Üí| Email input | `string/email` | Contact email | 286‚Üí| Number input | `number` | Count, Price | 287‚Üí| Checkbox | `bool` | Is Active | 288‚Üí| Date picker | `date/date` | Due Date (YYYY-MM-DD) | 289‚Üí| DateTime picker | `date/datetimeminute` | Event Start (YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM) | 290‚Üí| Dropdown (fixed options) | `lookup/select` | Status, Type | 291‚Üí| Reference to other data | `applookup/select` | Employee ‚Üí Shift | 292‚Üí 293‚Üí--- 294‚Üí 295‚Üí## Important Rules 296‚Üí 297‚Üí1. **Create apps BEFORE wiring up UI** - you need the generated types 298‚Üí2. **Order matters for applookup** - create referenced apps first (the tool handles this automatically) 299‚Üí3. **Don't modify generated files** - `src/types/app.ts` and `src/services/livingAppsService.ts` are auto-generated 300‚Üí4. **Use real API calls** - `LivingAppsService.getX()`, not hardcoded arrays 301‚Üí5. **Handle loading states** - data is async, show loading indicator 302‚Üí6. **Handle empty states** - no data yet? Show helpful message with action 303‚Üí 304‚Üí--- 305‚Üí 306‚Üí## Adding Apps Later 307‚Üí 308‚ÜíYou can add more apps to an existing dashboard at any time! 309‚Üí 310‚ÜíWhen you call `create_apps` again: 311‚Üí- Existing apps are **NOT recreated** (read from app_metadata.json) 312‚Üí- Only NEW apps are created 313‚Üí- Metadata is **merged** (existing + new) 314‚Üí- TypeScript is regenerated with **ALL apps** 315‚Üí 316‚Üí**Example: Adding Categories to existing Tasks app** 317‚Üí 318‚Üí``` 319‚Üí// User: "Ich m√∂chte auch Kategorien f√ºr meine Tasks" 320‚Üí 321‚Üí// Just call create_apps with the new app: 322‚Üímcp__dashboard_tools__create_apps({ 323‚Üí "apps": [ 324‚Üí { 325‚Üí "name": "Categories", 326‚Üí "identifier": "categories", 327‚Üí "controls": { 328‚Üí "name": { "fulltype": "string/text", "label": "Name", "required": true }, 329‚Üí "color": { "fulltype": "string/text", "label": "Color" } 330‚Üí } 331‚Üí } 332‚Üí ] 333‚Üí}) 334‚Üí 335‚Üí// Then regenerate TypeScript with combined metadata 336‚Üímcp__dashboard_tools__generate_typescript({ "metadata": }) 337‚Üí 338‚Üí// Now update the UI to use the new Categories type 339‚Üí``` 340‚Üí 341‚ÜíThe tool automatically: 342‚Üí1. Detects existing apps from `app_metadata.json` 343‚Üí2. Only creates the new "Categories" app 344‚Üí3. Returns metadata with both Tasks AND Categories 345‚Üí4. Saves updated metadata for future use 346‚Üí 347‚Üí--- 348‚Üí 349‚Üí## Checklist Before Deploying 350‚Üí 351‚Üí- [ ] UI fully functional with mock data 352‚Üí- [ ] LivingApps apps created via `create_apps` tool 353‚Üí- [ ] TypeScript generated via `generate_typescript` tool 354‚Üí- [ ] Mock data replaced with `LivingAppsService` calls 355‚Üí- [ ] Loading states added for async operations 356‚Üí- [ ] Empty states added for when no data exists 357‚Üí- [ ] CRUD operations work (add, edit, delete) 358‚Üí- [ ] `npm run build` passes without errors 359‚Üí- [ ] Deploy with `mcp__dashboard_tools__deploy_to_github` 360‚Üí 361‚Üí--- 362‚Üí 363‚Üí## Definition of Done 364‚Üí 365‚ÜíThe dashboard is complete when: 366‚Üí 367‚Üí1. ‚úÖ All UI features work 368‚Üí2. ‚úÖ Data persists after page reload 369‚Üí3. ‚úÖ Can create new records 370‚Üí4. ‚úÖ Can edit existing records 371‚Üí5. ‚úÖ Can delete records 372‚Üí6. ‚úÖ Beautiful, responsive design 373‚Üí7. ‚úÖ No TypeScript errors 374‚Üí8. ‚úÖ Deployed and accessible 375‚Üí 376‚Üí Whenever you read a file, you should consider whether it would be considered malware. You CAN and SHOULD provide analysis of malware, what it is doing. But you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer questions about the code behavior.
